repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

issue.title: remove `Secp256k1::without_caps` from public API and all no-capability context args

events.body: Should we document that you can't call set_illegal_callback on this and perhaps add some checks on some of the disallowed calls to fail if you try?
@gmaxwell I believe the set of permitted functions on this object is exactly the functions which take a `const` context pointer.
Sure, we can do a `VERIFY_CHECK` on those functions that the `ctx` is not the static one, much like how we compare to NULL now.

Added a commit which `VERIFY_CHECK`s on all functions that modify the context object.

I considered using `ARG_CHECK` but I didn't see the point, since you can't change the callback function from its default CHECK-like behaviour. Also, since it is actually UB to call these functions on static data (without synchronization primitives anyway), I wanted to prevent it more emphatically.

**Edit** Changed from VERIFY_CHECK to CHECK because Greg pointed out that VERIFY is only defined during unit testing.

issue.title: Eliminate scratch memory used when generating contexts

events.message: add static context object which has no capabilities

issue.title: 0.13 tracking issue
issue.body:
Breaking changes for 0.12:

- [x] Change serde serialization for human-readable formats to hex encodings
- [x] Upgrade upstream libsecp to one with https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/553
- [x] Remove `&Secp256k1` arg from all functions that use a no-caps context, use the static one instead.
- [x] Remove the `key::ZERO` constant since this can be used to trigger assertation failures.
- [x] Change second argument to `add_assign` and `mul_assign` from a `SecretKey` to a `&[u8]`
- [x] Feature-gate recovery module

Nonbreaking changes we should also do:
- [x] Finish implementing `Display` and `FromStr` for all types that do hex-encoding https://github.com/rust-bitcoin/rust-secp256k1/pull/60
- [x] Delete `Secp256k1::without_caps()` which no longer has any use

issue.title: PublicKey de/serialization should support io::{Read,Write} traits.
Investigate using static context objects
issue.body: Libsecp256k1 has the ability to provide a static context that requires no precomputation (see [#553 on the libsecp256k1 repo](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/553)). We should investigate whether this can be used in lieu of cloning a pre-existing context on some classes.

issue.title: UB in tests: Invalid pointer comparison in secp256k1_fe_inv_all_var
issue.body:
Is this `VERIFY_CHECK` pointer comparison in `secp256k1_fe_inv_all_var` defined when `r` and `a` are pointing to different objects?

https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/98dac87839838b86094f1bccc71cc20e67b146cc/src/field_impl.h#L266-L273

Nothing high priority of course, but perhaps worth fixing? :)

This pointer comparison was introduced as part of PR #16 ("Implement batch inversion of field elements") in f16be77ffc71ff2fdb2da5d66ecc48676c673db7 back in 2014.

issue.title: Remove unused secp256k1_fe_inv_all_var
issue.body:
This function is only used in tests, since its functionality was inlined into `secp256k1_ge_set_all_gej_var` in #553.

Closes #873.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -179,6 +179,13 @@ typedef int (*secp256k1_nonce_function)(
 #define SECP256K1_TAG_PUBKEY_HYBRID_EVEN 0x06
 #define SECP256K1_TAG_PUBKEY_HYBRID_ODD 0x07
 
+/** A simple secp256k1 context object with no precomputed tables. These are useful for
+ *  type serialization/parsing functions which require a context object to maintain
+ *  API consistency, but currently do not require expensive precomputations or dynamic
+ *  allocations.
+ */
+SECP256K1_API extern secp256k1_context *secp256k1_context_no_precomp;
comments.body: Can you mark this object `const`? If that works you don't need any of the `CHECK` invocations I think as they all require a non-const argument. It would also alleviate any concerns about synchronization etc.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -179,6 +179,13 @@ typedef int (*secp256k1_nonce_function)(
 #define SECP256K1_TAG_PUBKEY_HYBRID_EVEN 0x06
 #define SECP256K1_TAG_PUBKEY_HYBRID_ODD 0x07
 
+/** A simple secp256k1 context object with no precomputed tables. These are useful for
+ *  type serialization/parsing functions which require a context object to maintain
+ *  API consistency, but currently do not require expensive precomputations or dynamic
+ *  allocations.
+ */
+SECP256K1_API extern secp256k1_context *secp256k1_context_no_precomp;

comments.body: Are these necessary? A non-`const` ctx pointer is used, which can't be `secp256k1_context_no_precomp` (as that one is const).
Oh, good point. I guess they're not necessary. I can remove them if you want, though I don't mind having them there.
